frameDefinitions: A Whole separates into Parts, or one part of a whole, called Part_1, becomes separate from the remaining portion, Part_2.
Partner_1 and Partner_2 or a group of Partners  work together in some Undertaking.
These words refer to separating a Whole into Parts, or separating one part from another.
This frame contains words that describe a set of individuals which possess some Commonality, generally a common attribute.
A flying Vehicle comes to the ground at a Goal in a controlled fashion, typically (but not necessarily) operated by an operator.
A New filler occupies a Role or serves a Function after the Old filler ceases to occupy the position.
frameExamples: This small channel meanders through marsh and wetland, <t>splitting</t> into several smaller channels that empty into Lake St. Clair.
CSTR actively <t>collaborates</t> with the Departments of Artificial Intelligence  and Physics.
I <t>divided</t> the class into groups in alphabetical order .
A police helicopter <t>landed</t> just outside my neighborhood at around midnight last night.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Whole</fen> is a single entity or an aggregate of entities which separates into <fen>Parts</fen>.
This refers collectively to the Parts resulting from separation of a Whole:
Part-1 is the first of two Parts mentioned.
Part_2 is the second of two Parts mentioned. This is usually a PP Complement.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the separation occurs.
Where the separation occurs.

When the parties in a collaboration are expressed separately, this Frame Element marks constituents that express the one that is grammatically more prominent, i.e., the one that is the subject of an active clause.
This Frame element marks constituents expressing the grammatically  less prominent, typically oblique, party in a collaboration.
This frame element marks constituents that express the project in which the <fen>Partners</fen> are collaborating.
This frame element marks expressions that express the parties that work together in an <fen>Undertaking</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Partners</fen> are engaged in their collaboration.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the collaboration occurs.
The <fen>Whole</fen> is a single entity or an aggregate of entities which is separated into <fen>Parts</fen>.  It is usually the NP Object of a target verb.
This refers collectively to the Parts resulting from separation of a Whole:
Part-1 is the first of two Parts mentioned. This is most often the Object of a verb.
<fen>Part_2</fen> is the second of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. This is usually a PP Complement. First,
With causative uses of these verbs, an Agent separates or divides something.  The Agent is usually expressed as the External Argument:
The <fen>Cause</fen> is the non-agent that brings about the separation.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the separation occurs.
Where the separation occurs.

This role denotes the people in possession of the Commonality. This role is usually genetive, the object of a postnominal PP, or null instantiated (INI), and null instantiaton often implies the public at large, as in 'the common good'.
This role denotes an object or attribute which is jointly posessed by the <fen>Entities</fen>.
One of the possesors of the <fen>Commonality</fen>. Can be singular or plural.
One of the possesors of the <fen>Commonality</fen>. Can be singular or plural.
The <fen>Vehicle</fen> comes to the ground, usually (but not necessarily) under the control of an operator.
<fen>Goal</fen> is any expression that tells where the <fen>Vehicle</fen> ends up, or would end up, as a result of the motion.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the aircraft lands.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the landing occurs.
The new filler of the <fen>Role</fen> that was previously occupied by the <fen>Old</fen> filler.
The category that the <fen>New</fen> and <fen>Old</fen> entities fit into as a result of the <fen>Function</fen> they serve.
The (generally desirable) state of affairs that the <fen>New</fen> and <fen>Old</fen> entities are involved in bringing about.
The entity that occupied the <fen>Role</fen> or served the <fen>Function</fen> before the <fen>New</fen> filler.
The time at which the <fen>New</fen> takes up the <fen>Role</fen> previously occupied by the <fen>Old</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Metalworkers' union</fex> to split into regional divisions
These daughter chromosomes then begin to separate <fex>from each other</fex>, each moving away from the metaphase plate and toward one of the two spindle pole regions.
Initially, <fex>the front part</fex> separated from the rest of the body.
Initially the front split <fex>from the rest of the body</fex>
However it is believed they separated <fex>at least 2 if not 3 million years ago</fex>.
The two parts likely separated <fex>above the Atlantic</fex>.
<fex>Smithers</fex> collaborated with Chief Wiggum
Britain is collaborating <fex>with France and West Germany</fex> in the development of anti-tank missiles
The two artists collaborated <fex>on a mosaic</fex>.
<fex>Smithers and Chief Wiggum</fex> collaborated well
<fex>Last year</fex> some of my colleagues collaborated in the design of a theme-park.
<fex>In New Braunfels</fex> Paul and John collaborated in the design of a new Guggenheim
The directors split <fex>the company</fex> in two.
The directors split the company <fex>in two</fex>.
First, separate <fex>the yolks</fex> from the whites.
separate the yolks <fex>from the whites</fex>.
<fex>The researcher</fex> divided subjects into groups.
I divided the prize money among the winners <fex>that night</fex>.
You should separate the yolks from the whites <fex>over the sink</fex>.
<fex>Their</fex> common enemy was Britain.
Their shared <fex>parents</fex> were their only similarity.
<fex>He</fex> shares a home with us.
He shares a home with <fex>us</fex>.
<fex>The plane</fex> landed on the airstrip.
Most of the planes set down <fex>on the strip</fex> before midnight.
The traditional thatched roof has often been replaced <fex>by corrugated galvanized iron</fex>.
What gas replaced Hydrogen <fex>as a safer medium for use in balloons</fex> on account it does not burn?
Oil and gas replaced coal <fex>in heating homes, in industry, and in transportation</fex>.
The electron was discovered and <fex>electricity</fex> replaced gas lamps.
When electricity replaced oil <fex>in the early 1930's</fex>, the steady beam was replaced by a flashing light.
